<@990351294290092093> Can you help me understand how difference modules of a react JS project work?

Certainly! In a React project, modules are used to organize and break down your code into smaller, more manageable pieces. 

Typically, each module corresponds to a specific feature or functionality of your application. For example, you might have a module that handles authentication, another that deals with user profiles, a third that displays a list of items, and so on.

Each module typically contains its own set of components, logic, and data that are used to implement that particular feature. These modules can then be imported and used by other modules as needed.

<@990351294290092093> What’s the difference between Angular and  React?

Angular and React are two popular JavaScript frameworks used for building web applications. Here are some key differences between the two:

1. Angular is a complete framework that includes everything you need to build a web application, whereas React is a view library that focuses only on the UI.

2. Angular uses a template system for creating components, while React uses a syntax called JSX.

3. Angular is heavily opinionated and has a steep learning curve due to its complexity, while React is more flexible and easier to learn.

4. Angular uses two-way data binding, while React uses one-way data flow through props.

5. Angular has its own dependency injection system built-in, while React relies on external libraries like Redux

The cleanliness of a framework/library depends on the needs of your project and your personal preference as a developer. 

Angular has a lot of built-in features and is more opinionated, which can make it easier to get started with and to have a consistent codebase across teams. However, this could also lead to a larger and more complex codebase than necessary for smaller projects.

React, on the other hand, is more focused on building user interfaces and provides a lighter and more flexible approach than Angular. This can make it easier to maintain and extend your codebase in the long run but may require additional configuration for certain features.
